metadata.title: Sequentially-crosslinked bioactive hydrogels as nano-patterned substrates with customizable stiffness and degradation for corneal tissue engineering applications

Sequentially-crosslinked bioactive hydrogels as nano-patterned substrates with customizable stiffness and degradation for corneal tissue engineering applications
Muhammad Rizwan1,2, Gary S.L. Peh3,4, Heng-Pei Ang3, Nyein Chan Lwin3, Khadijah Adnan3, Jodhbir S. Mehta4,5,*, Wui Siew Tan2,*, Evelyn K.F. Yim1,6,7,8,^,*
1Department of Biomedical Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore 2Institute of Materials Research and Engineering, Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR), Singapore 3Tissue Engineering and Stem Cell Group, Singapore Eye Research Institute, Singapore 4Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School, Singapore 5Singapore National Eye Centre, Singapore 6Department of Surgery, National University of Singapore, Singapore 7Mechanobiology Institute, National University of Singapore, Singapore 8Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, Canada * Joint corresponding authors ^ Author’s current address: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ontario, Canada. Keywords: GelMA, nano-patterning, hydrogels, human corneal endothelium, hydrogel membrane, photo-crosslinking
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Abstract Naturally-bioactive hydrogels like gelatin provide favorable properties for tissue-engineering but lack sufficient mechanical strength for use as implantable tissue engineering substrates. Complex fabrication or multi-component additives can improve material strength, but often compromises other properties. Studies have shown gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) as a bioactive hydrogel with diverse tissue growth applications. We hypothesize that, with suitable material modifications, GelMA could be employed for growth and implantation of tissueengineered human corneal endothelial cell (HCEC) monolayer. Tissue-engineered HCEC monolayer could potentially be used to treat corneal blindness due to corneal endothelium dysfunction. Here, we exploited a sequential hybrid (physical followed by UV) crosslinking to create an improved material, named as GelMA+, with over 8-fold increase in mechanical strength as compared to regular GelMA. The presence of physical associations increased the subsequent UV-crosslinking efficiency resulting in robust materials able to withstand standard endothelium insertion surgical device loading. Favorable biodegradation kinetics were also measured in vitro and in vivo. We achieved hydrogels patterning with nano-scale resolution by use of oxygen impermeable stamps that overcome the limitations of PDMS based molding processes. Primary HCEC monolayers grown on GelMA+ carrier patterned with pillars of optimal dimension demonstrated improved zona-occludin-1 expression, higher cell density and cell size homogeneity, which are indications of functionally-superior transplantable monolayers. The hybrid crosslinking and fabrication approach offers potential utility for development of implantable tissue-engineered cell-carrier constructs with enhanced biofunctional properties.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The ability to create bioactive hydrogels with tunable stiffness and degradation is in great demand as material matrix degradation and stiffness have significant influences on cellular
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
responses and tissue growth [1]. Gelatin methacrylate (GelMA), a bioactive hydrogel, is increasingly being used in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Applications include cell encapsulation, cardiac and cardiovascular tissue engineering, bone, cartilage and muscle tissue engineering, and bioink development for 3D printing [2]. The rise in popularity of GelMA is due to its proven biocompatibility, physico-chemical tailorability and the possibilities it offers for patterning with spatio-temporal control of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels [2]. Several strategies to improve the mechanical properties of gelatin methacrylate hydrogels have been reported. These include reinforcement with 3D printed microfibers [3], carbon nanotubes [4, 5], graphene oxide [6], poly lactide-co-ethylene oxide-co-fumarate (PLEOF) [7], polyacrylamide [8] and polyethylene glycol [9, 10]. Biopolymers such as gellan gum [11], hyaluronic acid [12], dextran [13] and silk fibroin [14] have also been incorporated to tune the mechanical properties of GelMA. The reported strategies have thus far focused on the addition of another component to the GelMA and involve complex and often expensive processes. Room temperature crosslinking of Gel A macromer solution has also been shown to improve the modulus of GelMA hydrogels [15]. To date, there lacks a proven method able to tune the strength and biodegradation properties of GelMA for tissue engineering application. Requirement to use biocompatible materials and preferably minimal chemical modifications and minimal synthetic additives in the material formulation remains an unmet challenge. Similarly, the control of cellular fate by manipulating the cell behaviors with surface micro or nano-topographical cues is another key topic in biomaterials study. PDMS micro-molding and photolithography are the two most commonly used techniques for topographical patterning of hydrogels [16-18]. PDMS master molds have been used to pattern chemically crosslinked hydrogels such as alginate and PVA with nanoscale features [19-21]. However, PDMS micromolding of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels including GelMA has only been able to achieve feature size on the order of only 10s of micrometers [22-25]. The reason PDMS molds cannot
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
achieve high resolution pattering of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels, is likely due to the high oxygen diffusion coefficient of PDMS, which inhibits UV crosslinking at the hydrogel-PDMS mold interface [26, 27]. UV-crosslinking with N2 purging [28] or expensive quartz and silicon stamp-based nano-imprint lithography of hydrogels have been shown to enable high resolution patterning of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels [29, 30]. The ability to pattern UV-crosslinkable GelMA with topographical cues in the range of 1 µm or lower with cost-effective and simple methods would benefit further translational use of the material to control cellular functions and stem cell differentiation [31]. The relevance of these sizes is related to the fact that the in vivo extracellular matrix also contains nanoscale topographical cues [32]. An impaired human corneal endothelial cell (HCEC) monolayer due to Fuchs’ Endothelial Dystrophy (FED) or bullous keratopathy is one of the major causes of corneal blindness [33- 35]. It is also the leading indication for corneal transplantations, which is the only solution for corneal blindness [36]. Due to a worldwide donor cornea shortage, tissue-engineered HCEC transplants are being investigated as an alternative tissue source [33, 37]. HCECs may be implanted on a carrier or using a cell based approach [38]. The advantage of using a carrier is the ability to control cell density during the implantation process [39]. Ideally, the implantable film should be biocompatible and support HCEC adhesion, be optically transparent, permit diffusion of aqueous humor nutrient molecules and should be mechanically strong for easy handling by corneal surgeons [40]. Another distinct advantage of a synthetic carrier over a biological one would be the ability to slowly biodegrade after implantation. Previous research studies have utilized several synthetic and natural materials to fabricate a cell-carrier for HCEC monolayer transplantation [41-46]. While previous studies have laid the ground work and shown the potential of this method, the following important material properties for cellcarriers require further development: mechanical strength of the film in hydrated state, nutrient transport rates through the cell-carrier, biodegradation kinetics in relevant media, and effective support of the correct cell phenotype and relevant analysis [45]. Importantly, the
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
majority of cell-carriers in use today are “passive”. They act primarily as a transfer support for transplantation of monolayer and do not participate in enhancing the functional markers and phenotype of the regenerated monolayer. Corneal transplants often fail due to loss of the donor HCECs from the transplanted monolayer. Studies show that 30% of HCECs are lost within the first 6 months of transplantation [47, 48]. Designing implantable cell-carriers that not only serve as a transporter, but also enhance cell function and phenotype may improve the long-term success of corneal transplantation. Improving the cellular functions of the HCECs grown on the carrier would improve the cell-cell and cell-carrier adhesion, similar to native Descemet membrane (DM) [40]. In this study, we report on the development of highly tunable micro- and nano-patterned GelMA thin films and demonstrated its application in both tissue engineering and as cell-carrier support functions for HCEC monolayer culture and transplantation. We developed a simple method to improve GelMA mechanical strength over 8-folds and characterized our developed GelMA hydrogel in terms of compressive Young’s modulus, rheology, extent of UV-crosslinking, hydration characteristics, biodegradability in vitro and in vivo, and permeability of the GelMA films to bovine serum albumin (BSA) and glucose with and without cell monolayers. Additionally, we developed a generic and simple nano-molding method to pattern micro- as well as nano-topographical cues on hydrogels films and demonstrated the ability of topographical cues to improve the cell functions and phenotype of HCEC monolayer. 2. Experimental Section 2.1. Synthesis of gelatin methacrylate Gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) was synthesized as described previously [49] with modifications. Briefly, 5 g gelatin (Type A, Sigma Aldrich) was dissolved in 50 ml Phosphate Buffer Saline (PBS). Once fully dissolved, 10 ml methacrylic anhydride (Sigma Aldrich) was added dropwise to the gelatin solution at 60 ºC and the reaction was continued for 1 hr under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, the mixture was diluted with deionized (DI) water, filled in
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
12-14 kDa cut-off dialysis tubes and dialyzed in DI water for 5 days at 37 °C. After dialysis, the GelMA solution was frozen at -80 ºC and lyophilized to obtain white GelMA foam. The degree of methacrylation of gelatin was measured by using TNBSA assay, which was ≈ 89% in this work. 2.2. Preparation of GelMA hydrogels
Lyophilized GelMA was dissolved in PBS containing 0.5% w/v Irgacure 2959 (BASF) at 50 °C to prepare prepolymer solution. To prepare ‘regular’ GelMA hydrogel, the prepolymer solution at 37 °C was pipetted between glass slides separated by spacers (150-750 µm) and immediately crosslinked for 60 s by using UV irradiation (360-480 nm) at an intensity of 32 mW/cm2 (UVACUBE 100, Honle) (Figure 1). To prepare hybrid crosslinked GelMA hydrogel (GelMA+), the prepolymer solution was pipetted between glass slides and the glass slide chamber was incubated at 4 °C for 1hr. Immediately after incubation, the prepolymer was irradiated with UV light as described above (Figure 1). After crosslinking, the GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels were removed from glass slides. 2.3. Mechanical testing, FTIR, DSC, CD and XRD analysis
Hydrogel samples of 8 mm diameter and 1 mm thickness were prepared by crosslinking
prepolymer solution as described above to prepare GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels. The samples were incubated overnight in PBS at 37 °C. The samples were tested on an Instron mechanical tester at a constant compression rate of 0.5 mm/min with 10N load cell. The data was plotted as compressive stress-strain curve and the compressive modulus was calculated as the slope of the linear region of the stress–strain curve corresponding to 0%–15% strain. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed as described previously [11], To determine the fraction of unreacted methacrylate double bonds in 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels with same methacrylation degree and UV exposure time. To prepare samples for FTIR, hydrogels were lyophilized, made into KBr pellets and the spectra were
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
taken by a FTIR spectrometer (Shimadzu Scientific) with spectral data spacing of 6 cm-1. The FTIR spectra was corrected to remove peaks for water vapors and carbon dioxide (CO2). Circular dichroism (CD) spectra from 260 nm to 200 nm was recorded by using Jasco J-715 spectropolarimeter with a 0.1 cm path length cuvette. Gelatin and GelMA prepolymer solutions (0.1% w/v) were maintained at either 4 °C or 37 °C for 1 hr before recording the spectra. To investigate the gelation and melting phase transitions, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) plots were recorded on 30% GelMA solution and 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels (8-9 mg) in temperature range of 4 °C to 60 °C, at a ramp rate of 3 °C/min (TA Instruments Q2000). The GelMA solution was cooled to 4 °C and was maintained isothermally for 1 hr (similar to the hydrogel fabrication protocol) before reheating to 60 °C. The 30% gelatin solution was used as a control. Crosslinked 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogel films were air-dried [50] and analyzed with X-ray Diffractometer (Bruker D8 Discover, WatLab). 30% gelatin solution physically-gelled at 4 °C for 1 hr and air-dried at 4 °C was included as control. The diffractograms were obtained at 40 kV and 40 mA. The data was collected in the diffraction range of 10 to 60 degree at a rate of 0.8 degree/min. 2.4. Swelling and pore size analysis of hydrogels GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels with prepolymer concentration of 10 - 30 % and fixed degree of methacrylation were prepared in form of 1 mm thick films of 8 mm diameter and lyophilized to record the dry weight (Wd). Next, the hydrogels were re-hydrated in PBS buffer overnight at 37°C and the weight of the hydrogel in swollen state (Ws) was recorded. The percentage degree of swelling was measured as follows:
Degree of swelling (%) = [(Ws-Wd)/Wd] x 100%

US CR

PT ED
To measure the pore size, hydrogel films were freeze dried overnight, sputter coated with gold and imaged with SEM. The SEM images were analyzed in ImageJ and the pore size presented as the average of the maximum and minimum pore diameter. 2.5. Rheological testing
For rheological property measurements, GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogel disks of 20 mm diameter and 0.5 mm thickness were prepared and incubated overnight in PBS. Parallel plate geometry (20 mm) was used for dynamical rheological measurements in a TA Instruments AR-G2 rheometer. The samples were loaded onto the bottom plate of the rheometer and the upper plate was lowered slowly while monitoring the normal force value. The upper plate was stopped when the normal force value started to increase, which indicated that the plate was touching the sample surface. The final gap was in the range of 480-500 µm depending on the sample height. The tests were carried out in the linear viscoelastic region (LVR). To determine the effect of temperature on elastic modulus (G’) of the hydrogels, temperature sweep rheometry was performed from 16 °C to 40 °C at 1% strain and 1 Hz frequency. Few drops of water were added to the edges of the samples to avoid sample dehydration. 2.6. Fabrication of nanoimprinted PET masters Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) molds with micro- and nano-features were prepared from silicon mold by using soft lithography. The PDMS molds containing micro- and nano-pillar structures were used as masters to nanoimprint mirror-image patterns (wells) on polyethylene terephthalate (PET) film of 250 µm thickness (Goodfellow). The nano-imprinting of PET films was performed by using a desktop nanoimprint tool (NIL Technology) at a temperature of 175 °C under a pressure of 5 bar for 5 min.
2.7. Patterning of hydrogel films Imprinted PET films were used as master mold to pattern GelMA and hydrogels. PET masters with micro- and nano-wells were bonded to the glass in the center of glass slide. The spacers
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
of certain thickness were placed at either edge such that the gap between the PET master and the top glass slide was 150 µm. Another glass slide was placed on top and the warm (37 °C) GelMA prepolymer solution was pipetted between the glass slides and allowed to flow under capillary force to fill the chamber. Subsequently, the chamber was placed at 4 °C for 1 hr. After incubation, the pre-polymer was UV-crosslinked as described above. After crosslinking, the GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels with micro and nano-pillar patterns were detached from the chamber and incubated in PBS. 2.8. Characterization of PET and GelMA hydrogel patterns Patterned PET and hydrogel films were characterized in terms of pattern replication and fidelity by using scanning electron microscopy. Nano-imprinted PET films were sputter coated with gold prior to viewing. Hydrogel films were placed in 24-well plates and secured with PDMS rings to not allow contraction during sample preparation. The samples were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 1 h. After fixing, the samples were serially dehydrated in ethanol gradient, followed by incubation in hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS)(Sigma Aldrich) twice for 5 min each. Finally, the samples were dried by evaporation of HMDS and sputter coated with gold. Sputter coated PET and GelMA samples were imaged with SEM. 2.9. Bio-degradation and optical transmission of hydrogels The GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogel films of 8 mm diameter and 140 µm thickness were incubated in collagenase II enzyme solution for 7 days to measure the degradation rate. The concentration of enzyme was 1 U/ml, 10 U/ml and 20 U/ml. The enzyme solution was replaced daily to maintain the activity of the enzyme. Small sample of the solution was taken at regular intervals and the bio-degradation rate was measured by using BCA assay in terms of the total protein liberated from the hydrogel films as a result of the degradation. Optical transmission of the hydrated 140 µm thick GelMA+ films with 1x6 µmpH topography in visible UV spectrum was measured by using spectrophotometer (Tecan Infinite 200). 2.10. In vivo GelMA+ degradation study

All animals were treated according to the guidelines of the Association for Research in Vision and Ophthalmology’s Statement for the Use of Animal in Ophthalmic and Vision Research. This study protocol was approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of SingHealth, Singapore. Four New Zealand White rabbits (female, 2.5-3.0kg, 3 months old) obtained from the National University of Singapore and housed under standard laboratory conditions within SingHealth Experimental Medicine Centre Singapore, were used in this study. All animal surgeries and follow-up evaluations were performed under general anesthesia through intramuscular injections of xylazine hydrochloride (5 mg/kg; Troy Laboratories, Glendenning, NSW, Australia) and ketamine hydrochloride (50 mg/kg; Parnell Laboratories, Alexandria, NSW, Australia), along with a topical application of lignocaine hydrochloride (1%; Pfizer Laboratories, New York City, NY, USA). Unpatterned GelMA+ hydrogel was first trephined into a circular film of 6.0 mm in diameter with a 6.0 mm corneal trephine blade (Asico, Westmont, IL, USA). A 3.2 mm peripheral corneal incision was made with a keratome blade to facilitate the insertion of the 6.0 mm GelMA+ film. Holding the GelMA+ disc lightly with a straight tying forceps, the disc was carefully inserted into the rabbit’s anterior chamber of right eyes through the corneal incision. The film was not attached to the posterior cornea by air bubble or other technique. Following insertion of the GelMA+ film, the corneal incision was secured and closed with 10/0 nylon interrupted sutures. Following implantation of the GelMA+ film, all rabbits received a postoperative regime of topical steroid prednisolone acetate (1%; Allergan Inc, Parsippany-Troy Hills, NJ, USA) and topical antibiotic tobramycin (1%; Alcon) for 4 times a day. An intramuscular injection of dexamethasone sodium phosphate (1 mL/kg; Norbrook Laboratories, Newry, Northern Ireland, UK) was also administered once daily. The rabbits were then placed near a heat source and allowed to recover from the anesthesia in a quiet area, and subsequently monitored carefully for signs of gastrointestinal stasis daily for a week. This medication regime was also maintained for a week. Slit lamp photographs were taken with a
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE

Zoom Slit Lamp NS-2D (Righton, Tokyo, Japan) and anterior segment-optical coherence tomography (AS-OCT) scans of corneal cross-sections and measurements of corneal thickness were performed using a Visante AS-OCT (Carl Zeiss Meditec, Dublin, CA, USA). 2.11. Harvesting of GelMA+ films for Analysis The rabbits were euthanized under anesthesia at 4 months by an overdose of intracardiac injection of sodium pentobarbitone (85 mg/kg; Jurox, Rutherford, NSW, Australia). The GelMA+ films were carefully extracted from within the anterior chamber following excision from the globe, and analyzed for pore size after freeze drying. Non-implanted 30% GelMA+ films of similar dimensions were used as control. 2.12. Cell culture and seeding on patterned hydrogel films Research-grade donor corneas were obtained from the Florida Lions Eye Bank (Miami, FL, USA). Primary HCECs were isolated from donor corneas as described previously [51]. Primary HCECs for this study were used from donors aged between (Table S1). The protocols conformed to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki and the study was approved by the institutional review board of the Singapore Eye Research Institute and Singapore National Eye Centre. The HCECs were cultured as described previously [52]. HCECs at passage 3 were used to form monolayer in this study [33]. Unpatterned and patterned GelMA+ films of 6 mm diameter and 138±5 µm thickness were prepared and incubated in 4% amphotericin B (Sigma Aldrich) in PBS for 3 days at 37°C. Subsequently, the films were washed with PBS 3 times, sterilized with UV irradiation, and seeded with HCECs at a seeding density of 1500 cells/mm2. The cells were cultured on the films for 10 days in s-media, which consisted of human endothelial SFM supplemented with (Gibco) and 1% penicillin–streptomycin (Gibco) [52]. The media was changed every 2 days. 2.13. IF staining and analysis of functional markers and cell morphology For imaging of Na+/K+-ATPase and zona occluding (ZO-1), HCECs were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA) for 20 min and permeabilized in 0.05% Triton X-100 for 15 min.

PT ED
Subsequently, the cells were blocked with 10% goat serum and 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA) for 1 h. The cells were not permeabilized for Na+/K+-ATPase staining. ZO-1 and Na+/K+-ATPase were labeled respectively with mouse ZO-1 monoclonal antibody (BD Transduction) diluted to 5 µg/ml and mouse monoclonal IgG1 Na+/K+-ATPase a1 antibody (Santa Cruz) diluted to 5 µg/ml in 1% goat serum, both overnight at 4 °C. The films were then washed and incubated for 1 h in 2.67 µg/ml Alexa Fluor 488-conjugated goat anti-mouse antibody diluted in PBS, counterstained with 2 ng/ml DAPI in PBS for 15 min, and mounted onto microscope slides for imaging with Nikon A1R confocal microscope. To investigate the effect of surface topography on the expression of ZO-1, the images were captured at an interval of 2 µm in the z-direction and the z-stack was merged using the ‘‘maximum intensity projection’’ option in ImageJ. The quantification of ZO-1 fluorescence at cell–cell junctions was performed by using ZO-1 stained images in ImageJ as reported previously [52]. Cell area, coefficient of variation (CV) of cell area, and cell circularity of HCECs was analyzed by using ZO-1 stained cells, which outlined the cell boundary. Briefly the images were opened in ImageJ and the cell boundary was manually traced to measure morphometric parameters. CV is defined as the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean cell area multiplied by 100. Cell circularity is defined as 4 π (A/P2) where A is the cell area and P is the cell perimeter. 2.14. Permeability analysis A custom-made chamber (Figure S1) was used to measure the permeability of the 30% GelMA+ film to ensure that there was no leakage and films were not cracked when secured in the chamber. The permeability coefficient of the GelMA+ films was first measured without the cell monolayer by using BSA (65 kDa) and glucose (180.16 g/mol) as model molecules to establish a baseline. Then the HCECs were cultured on GelMA+ as described above to form monolayer on unpatterned and 1x6 µmpH patterned 30% GelMA+. The permeability coefficient of the films containing the confluent monolayer was measured.

The chambers were briefly washed with 70% ethanol following by washing twice with PBS buffer. Subsequently, the chambers were sterilized by using UV irradiation for 30 min and the 10 mm diameter GelMA+ films (effective area for diffusion = 28 mm2) with or without the cells were placed between the two parts of the chamber, fastened with plastic screws and placed in the 6 well plate with each well filled with either 3 ml cell culture media or PBS buffer. For BSA permeation, the upper compartment was filled with 2 mg/ml BSA in 280 µl PBS buffer. For glucose permeation, the upper compartment was filled with 0.58 mg/ml glucose in 280 µl PBS buffer or cell culture media [53]. The liquid in the receptor compartment was stirred by using magnetic stirrer. BSA permeability was measured by using BCA assay (Thermo Fisher Scientific) while the glucose permeability was measured by using glucose assay kit (SIGMA) [42].
2.15. Statistical analysis
Student’s t-test and One-way ANOVA with Tukey’s post hoc test was used to determine statistical significance of multiple comparisons. The statistical significance threshold was set at P ≤ 0.05. All data are presented as means ± SD.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
3.1. Effect of crosslinking process on mechanical strength and swelling of hydrogels Gelatin was methacrylated to obtain UV-crosslinkable gelatin methacrylate (GelMA) with ≈89% methacrylation as measured by using 2,4,6-trinitrobenzene sulfonic acid (TNBSA) assay. To determine the effect of concentration and sequential crosslinking, Young’s compressive modulus was measured. Increasing the concentration of the prepolymer solution from 10% to 30% resulted in a significant increase in the compressive strength of regular GelMA (UV- crosslinking only) (Figure 2a). When GelMA was incubated at 4 °C prior to UV exposure to achieve the hybrid GelMA+, the compressive strength also increased significantly
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
with increasing prepolymer concentration from 10% to 30% (Figure 2a). The GelMA+ consistently demonstrated higher strength (4.9-fold higher at 10% concentration, 4.1-fold higher at 30% concentration) as compared to regular GelMA (Figure 2a). The 10% regular GelMA hydrogel demonstrated 5.8 kPa compressive modulus while the 30% regular GelMA hydrogel demonstrated 56.7 kPa compressive modulus. In comparison, the compressive modulus of GelMA+ hydrogel at 10% concentration was 28.8 kPa, which increased to 233.3 kPa at 30% concentration. Overall, by increasing the GelMA concentration from 10% to 30% and including a pre-UV crosslinking 1 hr incubation at 4 °C, we were able to vary the hydrogel compressive modulus by 40-fold from 5.8 kPa to 233.3 kPa. Degree of swelling of the hydrogels is linked with the amount of the crosslinking, which ultimately affects the mechanical strength. In line with this understanding, in the regular GelMA hydrogel, the degree of swelling dropped from 778% to 336% as the concentration of the pre-polymer solution increased from 10% to 30% (Figure 2b). In the case of GelMA+ hydrogel, the degree of swelling dropped from 462% to 276% as the concentration of the prepolymer solution increased from 10% to 30%. Interestingly while the modulus of 30% GelMA+ was close to 5-fold higher than 30% GelMA, the degree of swelling of 30% GelMA+ was not drastically lower as compared to 30% GelMA. We further analyzed the GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels, and found significant differences in the microstructure of these hydrogels. The average pore size of the freeze dried GelMA hydrogel was larger as compared to GelMA+ hydrogel at 10%, 20%, 30% prepolymer concentration (Figure 2c). Notably, GelMA hydrogels were inhomogeneous, comprising a mixture of large voids interspersed with denser material containing smaller pores, as reflected by microstructural features seen in the SEMs of the freeze-dried gel samples (Figure 2c). In contrast, the GelMA+ hydrogels had more homogenous microstructures, particularly at higher pre-polymer concentrations (Figure 2c). The smaller and more uniform distribution of pores could be a key factor contributing to the superior mechanical properties of 30% GelMA+.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
3.2. FTIR, CD, DSC and XRD analysis of hydrogels To examine the potential crosslinking differences between GelMA and GelMA+, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was performed to determine the fraction of unreacted C=C double bonds of methacrylate groups that remained in the 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels after UV crosslinking [11]. The FTIR spectra obtained from the GelMA and GelMA+ samples displayed the characteristic bands of the gelatin backbone, namely the Amide A, Amide I, Amide II and Amide III (Figure 3a) [54]. Specifically, the spectra GelMA revealed a noticeable shoulder at 1634 cm−1 in region between 1700-1600 cm−1 (Inset of Figure 3a). This shoulder was absent in the case of GelMA+. The shoulder at 1634 cm−1 could be related to presence of unreacted C=C double bonds in GelMA. Comparatively, absorption in this region was not visible in the spectra of GelMA+. This suggests more complete reaction of C=C during UV-crosslinking of GelMA+. The effect of physical network formation on increasing subsequent chemical crosslinking efficiency has also previously been observed and reported [11]. We recorded the CD spectrum of both gelatin and GelMA prepolymer solutions at 4 °C and 37 °C to investigate the low temperature helix formation capacity of the methacrylated gelatin chains as compared to unmodified gelatin. The CD spectra showed a peak around 222 nm (Figure 3b) for both polymers incubated at 4 °C. This peak is associated with the presence of triple helices [55]. The peak for the GelMA prepolymer solution was slightly weaker as compared to that of unmodified gelatin. Both the gelatin and GelMA solutions did not show any such peak at 37 °C (Figure 3b), confirming that the helices only formed when solutions were incubated at 4 °C. The DSC data for GelMA solution showed an exothermic peak at around 15 °C (Figure 3c). The exothermic peak in GelMA occurred at a lower temperature than gelatin. Taken together with the CD data, this thermal transition is likely related to the formation of helices during cooling. The data reflects that methacrylation of gelatin chains reduced the amount of coil-to-
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
helix transition and also decreased the temperature of this transition. Thermal transitions were not detectable by DSC for the UV-crosslinked GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels. This suggests that thermo-reversible phase transformations were not present in the UV-crosslinked hydrogels. In addition, physical crosslinks (if any) existing within the crosslinked GelMA+ did not exhibit melting endotherms even upon heating to 60 °C. Physical network associations during pre-incubation at 4 oC for GelMA+ hydrogels could cause close packing of gelatin coils and regions of increased short range order. To investigate this, we conducted X-ray diffraction (XRD) of 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels, with gelatin as a control. The gelatin showed a peak at ~20.5 degree (Figure 3d). This peak has been associated with triple helices in the literature [56]. A low intensity peak was detected for GelMA+ at similar 2θ value that was not present for regular GelMA. This data suggests that some degree of short-range ordered domains relating to triple helix formation during physical gelation at 4 °C before UV-crosslinking persist in the GelMA+ hydrogel post UVcrosslinking. These domains were absent in Gel A hydrogels that were incubated at 37 °C before UV-crosslinking. 3.3. Effect of temperature on dynamic elastic modulus and swelling of hydrogels Since the physical crosslinking and gelation of gelatin is known to be thermally reversible, we tried to understand whether the extent of physically cross-linked region within 30% GelMA+ could change depending on temperature, particularly at room to body temperature. The effect of temperature on the strength of the hydrogels was analyzed by measuring the dynamic elastic modulus (G’) by temperature sweep rheometry from 16 °C - 40 °C. The upper temperature of the investigation was chosen as 40 °C to represent a slightly higher temperature than the physiological temperature of the body, where the films are intended to be used. In addition, this temperature range could also melt the gelatin triple helices if they are present in a thermally-reversible state [57]. The results revealed that the temperature sweep from 16 °C to 34 °C did not affect the G’ of the regular GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(Figure S2). However, a small drop in G’ was observed at temperature beyond 34 °C in GelMA+, which was not significant as compared to regular GelMA (Figure 4). Overall, the G’ of the GelMA+ hydrogel remained several folds higher as compared to GelMA hydrogel over the full range temperatures tested (9.1-fold higher at 16 °C; 8.1-fold higher at 40 °C) (Figure 4). From this study, we inferred that physiological temperatures are unlikely to significantly compromise the mechanical properties of GelMA+ hydrogel implants. 3.4. High resolution micro- and nano-molding of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels Apart from mechanical property tuning, we investigated the use of topographical cues to improve the functional characteristics of human corneal endothelial cell (HCEC) monolayer. Free-standing films of 30% GelMA+ with controlled thickness and micro- and nanotopographical patterns were fabricated. The thickness of the hydrogel cell carrier material was limited to 150 µm to accommodate the material in the limited space of the anterior chamber of the eye and to ensure efficient nutrient transport across the cell-carrier. Here we simultaneously controlled the thickness of the hydrogel film while patterning the hydrogel by taking advantage of capillary forces during molding process (Figure 5a). Our initial attempts to patterns the GelMA+ hydrogels by using micro-patterned PDMS master stamp failed for the feature sizes of 1 µm or less. Using poly terephthalate (PET) films as master stamps, we were able to achieve high yield patterning of UV-cross-linkable GelMA+ hydrogels with 1µm wells (Figure 5b). The PET master stamps were also able to offer high resolution patterning of other UV-cross-linkable hydrogels such as polyacrylamide (Data not shown). The freestanding GelMA+ films with thickness down to 10 µm patterned with 1 µm pillars of aspect ratio up to 3 or 1 µm wells of 1 µm depth were successfully fabricated using this method (Figure 5c). Figure 5d shows the successful replication of 250 nm pillars using PETstamp based nano-molding. The thickness of the patterned free-standing films could be controlled from ca. 10 µm to 1 mm with this method.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
To determine the effect of hydration in PBS buffer or cell culture media (swelling of topography) on the patterned 30% GelMA+, we patterned 40 µm gratings and viewed them with optical microscopy in cross section view (Figure 5e). For comparison, 10% GelMA+ hydrogels patterned with same topography were also included (Figure 5e). The 10% GelMA+ topography demonstrated 12% increase in the grating height and 7% increase in the grating width (Figure 5e). However, the dimensions of the topography for 30% GelMA+ did not change significantly, likely due to low degree of swelling (Figure 5e).
3.5. Effect of micro- and nano-topographical cues on the HCECs phenotype and morphology The functional characteristics of corneal endothelial cells cultured on patterned 30% GelMA+ hydrogels films (pattern details described in Table S2) were investigated. The cells were able to form HCEC monolayer with polygonal cell shapes on unpatterned and patterned GelMA+ films (Figure 6a, b). The confocal images showed that the expression of cell-cell tight junctional protein Zona occuludin-1 (ZO1) (Figure 6a) and Na+/K+–ATPase (Figure 6b) was modulated by the underlying micro or nano-topography. The Na+/K+–ATPase expression was lowest on unpatterned films. The highest expression was found on the square-array of 1µm pillars with 6 µm spacing (1x6 µmpS) and the hexagonal-array of 1 µm pillars with 6 µm spacing (1x6 µmpH) (Figure 6b). We also evaluated the ZO1 expression at cell-cell junctions [52]. The expression of ZO1 was significantly higher on 1µm square array pillars as compared to hexagonal array pillars (Figure 6c). In addition, 1x6 µmpS pillars had significantly increased amount of ZO1 expression as compared to unpatterned films and 250 nm pillars. Since the morphology has been associated with the functional behavior and quality of cultivated corneal endothelial cells [51], we further evaluated the morphology of the HCECs in the monolayer. The HCEC monolayer had the highest cell density on 1x6 µmpS (P<0.05) and 1x6 µmpH (P<0.001) as compared to unpatterned films (Figure 6d). The HCECs were
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
significantly smaller on 1x6 µmpH compared to unpatterned films (Figure 6e). Coefficient of variation of (CV) cell areas, was also lowest on 1x6 µmpH, indicating better homogenous cell sizes on these patterned films. Overall the results suggest that the GelMA+ films patterned with 1x6 µmpS topography could significantly increase the amount of ZO1 and Na+/K+– ATPase expression while 1x6 µmpH topography could induce favorable cell morphometry such as high cell densities, low cell areas and homogenous cell size, thus improving the quality of the regenerated HCEC monolayer. 3.6. Biodegradation, biocompatibility and optical transmittance of hydrogels Biodegradation of the 140 µm thick 30% GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogel films were evaluated in collagenase enzyme of different concentrations in terms of the gelatin protein liberated from the films (Figure 7a). Generally, increasing the collagenase concentration increased the biodegradation of the GelMA and GelMA+ hydrogels. Regular GelMA demonstrated higher biodegradation rate as compared to GelMA+ hydrogel at a given collagenase concentration. GelMA completely dissolved within one day in 20 U/ml and 10 U/ml collagenase. However, in 1 U/ml collagenase, 55% of the GelMA dissolved at the end of the time point (7 days). However, GelMA+ took two days to be completely dissolved in 20 U/ml and 7 days to be completely dissolved in 10 U/ml. In 1 U/ml collagenase, only 10% of the GelMA+ dissolved at the end of the time point (7 days) as compared to 55% for GelMA at the same collagenase concentration. The data suggested that the incorporation of physical crosslinking prior to UV exposure (GelMA+) also influenced the biodegradation behavior of the hydrogel, which could be tuned independently of pre-polymer concentration, methacrylation degree, or UV crosslinking time. In vitro biodegradation of unpatterned 30% GelMA+ hydrogel film was further assessed by measuring the biodegradation in the aqueous humor taken from rabbit eyes (Figure 7b). The GelMA+ films showed 22% degradation in aqueous humor after 7 days. The films were still intact after 7 days and could be handled with tweezers.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
In vivo studies were carried out to evaluate the biodegradability and biocompatibility of the GelMA+ material in the anterior chamber of rabbit eyes. Unseeded, unpatterned GelMA+ films were inserted as free-floating films into the rabbit anterior chamber, without attaching to the posterior cornea for this study. To study the biodegradation, 30% GelMA+ film was implanted in the anterior chamber of rabbit eyes for 4 months to determine the effect of the anterior chamber environment on the film. The corneal thickness of the rabbits with the GelMA+ film implanted remained normal throughout the length of the study. Figure 7c shows a GelMA+ film in the anterior chamber of rabbit eyes at day 10 of implantation. The pores of the post-implanted GelMA+ films were significantly larger (pore size = 83.3±11.1 µm), which was in stark contrast with the control GelMA+ films that had not been implanted (pore size = 41.2±3.3 µm) (Figure 7d, e). As the GelMA+ material degraded and liberated from the films, the pores increased in size. This was in line with the previous findings that the biodegradation results in increased pore size [58]. However, the free-floating films maintained physical integrity and could be harvested from the anterior chamber without disintegration, indicating a slow degradation behavior. We did not use the BCA assay to measure the degradation rate quantitatively as were used for in vitro degradation experiments. In vivo implanted films are susceptible to absorb proteins from the aqueous humor. Therefore, the BCA assay to measure the total remaining protein content in the hydrogel films after degradation would give inaccurate measurement of the protein remaining in GelMA+ film. However, in the in vitro experiment (BCA assay), the protein released from the GelMA+ films in the aqueous humor degradation medium could be corrected by subtracting the protein concentration of the whole aqueous humor, which was used as control. To evaluate the biocompatibility of the GelMA+ material in the anterior chamber of rabbit eyes, the slit lamp images of the rabbit corneas over the period of 4 months demonstrated that the free-floating GelMA+ films were biocompatible (Figure 8). The corneas and the GelMA+ films remained clear over the period of the study and corneas did not show any inflammatory
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
response, except for rabbit 3 that showed neovascularization of the cornea at earlier time point (Rabbit 3, Day 15 in Figure 8). However, the neovascularization disappeared at later time points in rabbit 3 as well. An ideal material for corneal endothelial cell monolayer carrier should be transparent to visible light. The optical transparency of the 1x6 µmpH patterned 30% GelMA+ films of 140 µm thickness ranged between 90-92% in the visible range which was comparable to the optical transparency of the cornea (Figure S3) [59]. The films that were implanted in vivo also remained transparent over the course of 4 months, as can be seen in the images (Figure 8).
3.7. Permeability of hydrogel films One of the important criteria for materials selection for corneal endothelial tissue engineering is the permeability, where the permeability of the cell carrier device should be higher than the corneal endothelial cell monolayer to allow nutrient transport. We developed an acrylic-based custom-made system to measure the permeably of hydrogel thin films, which prevented film rupture during film mounting and leakage during experiment (Figure S1). Glucose is a major source of nutrients in the aqueous humour [42, 53]. The films were found permeable to BSA as well as glucose molecules with permeability coefficient of 2.2x10-7 cm/s for BSA (PBSA) and 2.7x10-5 cm/s for glucose (PGlu)(Figure 9a,b). PGlu was ca. 123 times higher as compared to PBSA, as glucose is much smaller in size. The GelMA+ permeability for glucose in our study was higher than the permeability of the corneal endothelium to sucrose (of similar molecular weight to that of glucose) [60]. From these permeability studies, GelMA+ films are not expected to limit the transport of nutrients to the cornea by HCEC monolayer. The permeability of the regular GelMA was slightly higher as compared to the GelMA+ for glucose molecule (Figure S4). However, the GelMA+ film was chosen as the material of choice due to its overall favorable properties as a cell carrier for HCEC monolayer.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Going further, we studied the nutrient permeability through corneal endothelial monolayers cultured on GelMA+ films. The HCEC monolayers on unpatterned as well as on patterned GelMA+ films were compared in terms of glucose diffusional permeability (Figure 9c). For the patterned films, 1x6 µmpH topography was chosen as it significantly improved the functional characteristics of HCEC monolayer. The HCEC monolayers on unpatterned as well as on patterned GelMA+ films were functionally active in terms of glucose diffusional permeability (Figure 9c). The PGlu of the HCEC monolayer on patterned GelMA+ films was 27% higher, as compared HCEC monolayer on unpatterned GelMA+ films. 3.8. Implantability testing in an implantation device Cell carrier film should be able to conform into a coiled configuration within an insertion device during endothelial keratoplasty surgery. The GelMA+ film was tested for its (i) ‘implantability’ in terms of pliability as it was coiled by the device during passage, (ii) ability to withstand the forces when pulled through the device with loading forceps and (iii) the damage to HCEC monolayer during the procedure. The 6 mm diameter GelMA+ films with HCEC monolayer were passed through the Endoglide endothelial keratoplasty insertion device, which is an implantation device used by cornea surgeons [61, 62]. The tests demonstrated that the films were capable of withstanding the implantation procedure in the Endoglide device without any visible damage (Figure 10). Live/dead assay showed very few cells were killed, by the process of loading the device, and also following film removal. Importantly, the HCEC monolayer did not detach from the GelMA+ film during testing.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
This study presented a simple method of fabrication of mechanically strong gelatin methacrylate hydrogels with several fold improvement in strength by exploiting the hybrid (physical + covalent) crosslinking in gelatin. Furthermore, a generic and simple nano-molding method was developed to improve the patterning resolution of hydrogels, allowing significant
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
enhancement of HCEC monolayer functional development. Our optimal material was transparent, provide adequate nutrient transport and robust to endure surgical implantation processes. Our results demonstrated the utility of a strong and patterned film as a superior biomaterial cell carrier device for corneal endothelial monolayer formation and implantation. The increased strength of GelMA+ could be attributed to the effect of triple helix and physical network formation during the incubation at 4 °C prior to UV crosslinking. CD data showed that gelatin modified with methacrylate groups retained its ability to form triple helices when incubated at 4 °C. The formation of helices and physical associations prior to UV-crosslinking resulted in GelMA+ with significantly higher compressive and dynamic modulus. This increase in modulus is likely due to combined effects of retained physical associations and more efficient UV-crosslinking. Previous studies have similarly demonstrated that cooling induced formation of physical associations within gelatin gels prior to enzymatic crosslinking resulted in a higher covalent crosslink density, which was attributed to the increased proximity of chains brought together by the physical crosslinks [63]. In our study, FTIR data similarly suggest higher crosslinking efficiency for GelMA+ gels UV-cured after 4 °C incubation, wherein unreacted C=C bonds were detectable in GelMA (cured without 4 °C incubation) but not in GelMA+. CD and DSC characterization show that physical associations and triple helix formation occurred during incubation at 4 °C. The increased efficiency of crosslinking in GelMA+ was likely due to the physical associations that brought the gelatin chains and their functional groups closer together, increasing their chance for reaction during UV crosslinking. XRD analysis also suggested that GelMA+ hydrogels retained regions with short-range order after UV-crosslinking. Such regions were absent from UV-crosslinked GelMA of the same formulation. Overall, we found that the formation of a physical gel at 4 °C prior to UV crosslinking resulted in triple helix and physical network formation, which increased covalent crosslinking density, and provided for a more homogeneous microstructure
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
as compared to regular GelMA. The combined effects contributed to the improved mechanical properties of the GelMA+ hydrogels. Another area of concern is whether the increment in modulus arose solely from additional physical crosslinking may be lost when being exposed to physiological temperatures. It is interesting to note that in a previous study, enzymatically cross-linked gelatin hydrogels with pre-formed physical networks exhibited reduced strength at temperatures above 37 °C [57, 64]. Temperature controlled rheological studies showed that our GelMA+ hydrogels did not exhibit significant loss of mechanical stiffness with increase in temperature from 10 °C to 40 °C. As opposed to UV crosslinking where chain proximity could enhance the chances for reaction, in the case of enzyme based crosslinking, the authors speculated that the formation of physical chain associations could instead limit the access of the enzyme to crosslinking sites [57]. While physical crosslinks in the enzymatically cross-linked gels studied by Bode et al. came apart above 37 °C temperature [57], in our case, the physical crosslinks seem to be stabilized by the covalent crosslinks formed during UV exposure, such that the mechanical properties remained stable up to 40 °C and no melting transitions were observed by DSC with heating up to 60 °C. This shows that the strength of the GelMA+ will not be adversely affected when used at physiological temperatures. The enzymatic biodegradation data showed that the GelMA+ degraded more slowly as compared to the GelMA hydrogels at a given concentration. Rate of biodegradation was generally associated with the prepolymer concentration and degree of crosslinking. The slower degradation kinetics of GelMA+ was thus in line with our other evidence of GelMA+ containing a higher crosslink density compared to GelMA. Our biodegradation study was the first demonstration that degradation kinetics can be effectively modified by incorporating hybrid crosslinking through pre-cooling of the gelatin base material before UV crosslinking. The ability to tune the degradation rates of GelMA+ will likely be useful for the development of tissue engineering scaffolds with controlled degradation during tissue regeneration [65, 66].
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
The slow degrading GelMA+ hydrogels could also be effectively employed in degradationmediated sustained and slow release of drugs from the matrix over long periods of time. A wide range of polymeric cell culture substrates as well as some metallic and non-UV crosslinkable hydrogels substrates have been patterned with high resolution micro- and nanotopographical cues to direct the essential cellular processes of seeded cells such as proliferation, contact guidance, morphology, and stem cell differentiation [32, 67-69]. However, the patterning of UV-crosslinkable hydrogel surfaces at submicron and nanometer scale remained challenging [2, 22-25]. One of the drawbacks of soft lithographic approaches using PDMS molds is the oxygen inhibition of the UV initiated free-radical reaction [70]. Oxygen inhibition results in under-cured adhesive surfaces and loss of surface properties [70]. PDMS is highly permeable to oxygen and other gases [71, 72]. The permeation of oxygen through PDMS inhibits UV-crosslinking near the PDMS surface. Oxygen permeation through PDMS affects UV crosslinking where the effect has been estimated to a depth of 4-5 µm. However, the top 1 µm layer in contact with the stamp is affected severely by the oxygen inhibition [73]. While the inhibition of a 1 µm layer for patterning low resolution features of 10s of µm in size is not damaging, the effects of oxygen inhibition is prohibitive for the formation of submicron features. Here, we demonstrated that high resolution micro- and nano-molding of UV cross-linkable GelMA could be achieved by overcoming oxygen permeability related limitations of PDMS using material with low oxygen permeability (PET) as a stamp. PET has several order of magnitude lower permeability for oxygen as compared to PDMS [74] and enabled successful high resolution micro- and nano-molding. The use of PET as a stamp material could offer unique advantages over traditional PDMS based stamps as PET can be thermally imprinted with much smaller feature sizes as compared to PDMS [75]. The wear of the master stamp features and the clogging of the features due to residual hydrogel limits the use of the master stamp to only 10-15 times. Thus, the use of the Si or quartz master stamp directly for hydrogels would increase the fabrication cost significantly. In
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
comparison, PET is a relatively inexpensive material. Several hundred copies of PET stamps can be prepared from one Si or quartz mold, which significantly lowers the overall cost. The majority of corneal transplants are performed due to corneal endothelial dysfunction. A tissue engineered approach aims to develop an alternative solution by using cultivated HCECs to generate a transplantable monolayer [45]. The ultimate aim is to reduce the dependence on donor corneas. The advent of advanced surgical procedures of transplanting HCEC monolayers, such as endothelial keratoplasty, have stimulated the efforts to find a suitable carrier, which could be used to grow and transplant the HCEC monolayer [76]. Improvement in the strength of the thin films in the hydrated state while maintaining a thin film for improved nutrient transport after surgery, could be the key to develop a successful cell carrier material. The current standard surgical procedure of endothelial keratoplasty requires a significant learning curve due to the delicate nature of the thin (approx. 100 microns) stroma/DM/endothelial cell complex [40]. Insertion devices (as used in this study) have improved the outcomes following surgery with respect to endothelial cell counts. The ability to transplant a thin bioengineered GelMA+ carrier that would biodegrade slowly over time could improve outcomes even further with respect to visual acuity results, since the carrier would dissolve just leaving the cell monolayer. The other important properties for corneal use include cell adhesive ligands, optical transparency and nutrient permeability. GelMA+ hydrogel contains naturally present cell adhesion ligands. Therefore, it can support the cellular adhesion without the use of ECM coatings. Rationally designed materials not only could provide mechanical support for HCEC monolayer delivery, but could also improve the functionality of the monolayer. We have previously demonstrated micro- and nano-pillars induced improvement in the functional markers of primary HCECs on polystyrene (PS) cell culture substrates [52]. However, PS cannot be used as a cell-carrier device due to lack of biodegradation and permeability. Here we developed a hydrogel that was strong in hydrated state when fabricated into thin films and patterned it with same pillars as reported in our
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
previous study [52, 77]. Additionally, we included the pillars with hexagonal array to study the effect of arrangement of topographical cues on the cellular behavior. Square array 1 µm pillars of 6 µm spacing, which were shown to improve the tight cell-cell junctional protein expression of HCECs on polystyrene [52], also improved the ZO1 expression of the HCECs on GelMA+ films. Changing the arrangement of the pillars from square to hexagonal lead to homogenous cell sizes and smaller cell areas, which are critical parameters to assess the quality of the cultivated HCECs [51]. The inclusion of ECM surface topography on cellcarrier device provides a way not only to provide a substrate and mechanical support for the HCEC monolayer transplantation, but also to provide the micro-environment to improve the functional markers of HCECs simultaneously. Degradation of the cell carrier film for HCEC monolayer transplantation has not been well studied in the past, especially in an aqueous humor environment. The degradation rates could affect the stability of the transplanted monolayer, where fast degradation could potentially cause failure of the graft due to insufficient development of the HCECs adhesion with the posterior corneal surface as the carrier film degrades. Slower degradation, on the other hand, could provide sufficient time for the transplanted HCEC monolayer to adapt to the environment and establish strong contact with the posterior corneal surface. The 30% GelMA+ degradation rates in collagenase, in extracted aqueous humor and in rabbit eyes suggest slow degradation kinetics where it could take several months to dissolve, thus providing enough time for the HCEC monolayer to form contact with posterior stroma [39]. As the GelMA+ film is optically transparent and permeable, the slower degradation reduces the risk of deleterious effects to the functioning of the HCEC monolayer in terms of nutrient delivery to the cornea without affecting vision. Future studies would be conducted to evaluate the transplantation of HCEC monolayer with patterned GelMA+ cell carrier and the functioning, attachment and survival of the cells following surgery in animal models of endothelial disease.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
We described a method, which demonstrated that the addition of a simple cooling step to gelatin methacrylate fabrication process allows us to exploit sequential hybrid (physical + UV) crosslinking to achieve improved properties of GelMA+ over GelMA that was UV cured without physical gelation conditions. The presence of a physical network of gelatin was the likely source of improved homogeneity and the efficiency of UV crosslinking. The resulting GelMA+ was close to 5-fold stronger in terms of Young’s compressive modulus and close to 9-fold stronger in terms of dynamic elastic modulus. We also showed that the increased strength of GelMA+ was thermally-stable at physiological temperatures. The GelMA+ had slow biodegradation kinetics as compared to regular GelMA. PET stamps with low oxygen permeability were used to enable high resolution pattering of UV-crosslinkable hydrogels. With our method, we were able to study micron and sub-micron topographically patterned GelMA+ substrate-cell interactions. HCEC monolayers grown on 1 µm pillars of square-array GelMA+ demonstrated improved zona-occludin-1 expression while monolayers on 1 µm pillar of hexagonal-array GelMA+ exhibited higher cell density and homogeneity of cell size, which are indicative of a functionally-superior monolayer. Implantability of the GelMA+ films with HCEC monolayer was tested in a corneal endothelial transplantation device and the result indicated minimum damage to cells layer and no damage to cell-carrier film. The GelMA+ films pose insignificant hindrance to nutrient transport. Our study presents GelMA+ as a customizable biomaterial that can effectively meet requirements for a viable implantable HCEC cell-carrier device. With optimized properties and incorporation of topographical patterns, GelMA+ thin films can effectively serve as a mechanical support and provide relevant cues to tissue-engineer superior transplantable monolayers for corneal endothelial dysfunction patients.
